abstract_summ: The WHO coined the acronym SARS (severe acute respiratory syndrome) and subsequently the causative virus as SARS‐CoV. In the summer of 2012, epidemic of pneumonia occurred again in Saudi Arabia which was subsequently found to be caused by another novel coronavirus.The Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is a novel coronavirus first identified in Wuhan, China, and the etiological agent of Coronavirus Disease-2019 (COVID-19).Many viral respiratory infections can cause severe acute respiratory symptoms leading to mortality and morbidity.In this review, we focus on our current understanding of epidemiology, pathogenesis, diagnostics and therapeutics of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19).Many respiratory viral infections such as influenza and measles result in severe acute respiratory symptoms and epidemics.BACKGROUND: Human infections with zoonotic coronaviruses (CoVs), including severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS)-CoV and Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS)-CoV, have raised great public health concern globally.
title_summ: Overview: The history and pediatric perspectives of severe acute respiratory syndromes: Novel or just like SARSNovel Coronavirus: Current Understanding of Clinical Features, Diagnosis, Pathogenesis, and Treatment OptionsThe cardiovascular burden of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) with a focus on congenital heart diseaseCOVID-19 Tragic Pandemic: Concerns over Unintentional “Directed Accelerated Evolution” of Novel Coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) and Introducing a Modified Treatment Method for ARDSCOVID-19: A promising cure for the global panicIdentification of a novel coronavirus causing severe pneumonia in human: a descriptive studyThe Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus-2 (SARS CoV-2) in Dentistry.Clinical Characteristics and Differential Clinical Diagnosis of Novel Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19): latest developments in potential treatmentsAn update on the status of COVID-19: a comprehensive review.Management of Biological Risk in Dental Practice
